entries.name: Chapter 1: Introduction
entries: The Haunt 3 is designed to be both a one-shot on its own merits, and a sequel to the bestselling adventures The Haunt and The Haunt 2. It is a Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition horror themed fantasy adventure.

This is a very challenging adventure for 7th level player groups of 3 to 5 players with some deadly encounters. However, ideally, The Haunt 3 is tailored as a medium difficulty adventure with plenty of excitement and danger for an 8th level party of 4 to 5 players.

entries.name: Adventure Synopsis
entries: The Haunt 3 picks up some time after the events of The Haunt 2. Designed for survivors of the first two, or new parties to equally enjoy, this adventure takes the party on a trip through time and mind to attempt to save the soul of Carol Anne. The adventure revisits locations from the first two and adds an entirely new location; the space between, a pocket world in the ruins of the village. The story begins with the party's dreams being haunted by an apparition of a young girl who appears to have half a porcelain doll face and half a human face.

The girl beckons them to come to St. Greycastle and step into the space between. Though it makes little sense, each party member feels a strong pull to this accursed place. If the party played The Haunt and The Haunt 2 they absolutely recognize Carol Anne and may be taken aback by her new appearance. If not, they will likely be intrigued by the spectral girl. Do they have what it takes to save Carol Anne's soul from the terrors of the Haunt?

entries.name: Running the Adventure
entries: This adventure is essentially a trip through time, offering the party a number of objectives by which to save Carol Anne from her dark fate as the Evil Doll. The encounters can be run in chronological order, or rearranged as the DM sees fit. The Haunt 3 is split up into 4 chapters:

items: Chapter 1: Introduction (this chapter)
Chapter 2: The Space Between
Chapter 3: The Quests
Chapter 4: Endings

entries: To run this adventure, you need the Dungeons & Dragons Player's Handbook (PHB), Monster Manual (MM), Dungeon Master's Guide (DMG), and the information found within this adventure module. Although the stat blocks are listed in Appendix A, a copy of Mordenkainen's Tome of Foes (MToF), Monsters of the Guild (MotG), and Tomb of Annihilation (ToA) is not required but may come in handy.

entries.name: Set the Mood
entries: It is highly advised to run this adventure with dim lighting (or candle-lit), spooky organ music, and have a creepy children's lullaby ready to play. This ensures the right vibe is achieved, and provides maximum satisfaction for you, the DM, and your players.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: This adventure is designed to utilize the Milestone Leveling System, by which it is expected that the characters start at level 8 at the beginning of the adventure, and upon escaping Montarthas Manor, they advance directly into level 9.

This is only a suggestion, however, and you, as the DM, are in no way forced to use this method. This adventure runs perfectly fine with the experience points based leveling, and you are encouraged to use XP if it is a better fit for you and your group.

entries.name: Boxed Text
entries: This adventure includes boxed text to assist those Dungeon Masters who like to have a description of a scene or location. The use of boxed text is by no means required; many great Dungeon Masters avoid the use of boxed text and instead feel more comfortable describing the action in their own words. You should consider what works best for you and your group. If you choose not to read aloud any of the text provided, you should at least paraphrase the information to keep the players aware of their environment.

entries.name: Setting and Location
entries: The Haunt 3 is designed to be a drop and play adventure that can fit into any setting and any campaign.

entries.name: Background
entries: In ages past, there once stood a small city. The city, being subject to constant orc attacks, maintained a defensive militia to ward away such attacks as they occurred. This militia stood for centuries and many commanding officers came and went throughout the years. Lady Margery Greycastle, a holy warrior in service to the Church of Ilmater, ended her adventuring career and sought to settle down somewhere where she could retire from travel and chaos, but still do good work and help the common folk. The city provided the perfect opportunity to do both, and the aging paladin served as a healer, spiritual guide, and support personnel to the city's militia in her late years.

Eventually, age and illness began to take their toll, and Lady Greycastle began preparations to leave the world. She made arrangements to leave the remainder of her funds, her house, and her property to the city for conversion into a hospital.

St. Greycastle's Hospital served the city through the years, mainly treating the wounded and sick among the militia. Over time, the lower basement was converted into a sanatorium, housing those who became maddened from enduring the violent, brutal orcs raids which plagued the region.
General Oscar Montarthas, known for being fair, firm, and stern towards his men, rose through the ranks and assumed command over the city's militia. He was the last to command this post.

Not long from retirement, General Montarthas employed an advisor, Gertrude, who would assist the General in decision making with the forthcoming yearly orc invasions. This advisor was, in fact, an evil night hag, who planned to ruin the city and use its population to feed from the power of their life force. This was achieved by seducing the General and corrupting his heart.
As Gertrude the Hag began exerting her influence over the city at large, the sanatorium began to overfill with those who were driven mad by the abuses and tortures of the evil fey monster.

Gertrude took a particular pleasure in tormenting the sick, wounded, and mad. She also used the hospital as something of a training ground for Carol Anne Montarthas to grow accustomed to her new form as the Evil Doll. The hag taught her fledgling plaything to use her powers and to learn an appreciation for the art of terrorizing her prey.

Heavily undermanned, the city ultimately fell to the orcs and was abandoned, with only the manor standing the test of time. In recent memory, Montarthas Manor, and the hag that called it home, was brought down by the heroic efforts of adventurers who stumbled upon the ruins. The events of The Haunt not only brought an end to Gertrude and Montarthas Manor, but also led to Carol Anne's awakening as the Evil Doll. Reeling from these events, the Evil Doll went to the ruins of St. Greycastle's to heal on the dark energies there. The Haunt 2 detailed adventurers finding their way into St. Greycastle's, learning the truth of what transpired there, and seemingly laying those dark spirits to rest.

Unfortunately, rest was not to be had for Carol Anne. Her spirit now caught between the corruption of the Evil Doll, and the innocence of her stolen childhood, Carol Anne is caught outside of time. She has a plan to free herself from the Hag's influence and possibly undo the damage done to her childhood home, but to make it work, she needs brave adventurers to face the demons of her past. Perhaps these are the same adventurers who have faced The Haunt before, or perhaps new blood is needed.

entries.name: Adventure Hooks
entries: The adventure does not have any setting specific adventure hooks and relies on visitations within the party's nightmares to get the ball rolling for the story. If characters have played through the previous installments of The Haunt franchise, they should need no further encouragement to get involved in the adventure. If not, you may consider the following:

items: A survivor from previous excursions to Montarthas Manor contracts the group to help investigate the cause of strange nightmares. Once the party accepts the job, they too begin sharing the nocturnal visions.

entries.name: Chapter 2: The Space Between
entries: Once the party begins their journey to the ruin, they start to notice a number of counterclockwise spirals occurring around them. Everything from when they stir a pot of soup (regardless of direction) to leaves blowing in the wind, to the splash made when skipping a rock along a lake. Counterclockwise spirals are showing up everywhere, and more frequently as they approach the ruin.
Once the group arrives at the ruins of St.  Greycastle's Hospital, they find a macabre sight.
Read or paraphrase the following:

Where the ruins of St. Greycastle's Hospital once stood, you see a twisted mockery of a graveyard. Broken rocks, chunks of wall, and rotten wood are jammed haphazardly into the ground. Some sticky fluid, perhaps sap... perhaps blood, lists the names of the presumed deceased on these makeshift markers. Next to each name, in the same viscous fluid, is a counterclockwise spiral.

The detritus left behind from the battle of The Haunt 2 has been moved and reorganized to resemble a primitive model of a graveyard, complete with names of various NPCs from the previous installments (or perhaps friends/party members who died on the last play through).
The names are written with tree sap, or some other dark, sticky fluid, and in the drips of the fluid, spiral patterns have formed, again moving counterclockwise.

Characters who are proficient in Arcana or who succeed on a {@b {@dc 10} Intelligence (History)} check should be able to work out that walking widdershins around the cemetery (i.e. in a counterclockwise fashion, along with the spiral) may have some effect. According to folklore, this awakens or angers spirits in the region. If no characters can come to this conclusion on their own, they are considered to have failed the first challenge (see below). They hear a voice that implores them to "walk the spiral," which repeats until they walk widdershins, entering the Space Between.

entries.name: A Macabre Meeting
entries: When the party walks widdershins around the cemetery, read or paraphrase the following:

As you walk counterclockwise around the graves, you hear a low hum. The color begins to drain out of your surroundings as everything becomes a sickly gray. The hum grows louder and begins to take on a staccato quality. As you finish your lap around the cemetery, the hum has morphed into the weeping of a young girl.
Before you, among the graves, stands Carol Anne's ghostly reflection. Half flesh, half doll, the girl looks up at you and smiles.
"I'm glad you came."

Carol Anne explains that in death she has found a mechanism to unwind time, but in order to undo the damage done to her, she needs to establish anchors in the past, one for each year of her mortal life. These are established by physical interaction, often defeating a monster or monsters of the past.

She explains that finding the Space Between was the first test and congratulates them on succeeding (or chastises them for failing, in the event that she had to explain the process to them.) If the party agrees to help her and undo the evil, she describes the objectives, and asks them to choose their starting point.
Once the encounter is chosen, Carol Anne instructs them to walk widdershins in the Space Between and they are sent off on their first quest.
Each time the group succeeds or fails, they are brought back to the Space Between until Carol Anne is freed, or the group fails a total of six quests.

entries.name: Chapter 3: The Quests
entries: The following quests can be completed in any order. Depending on how things proceed, the party ends with The Good (4.1), The Bad (4.2), or The Ugly (4.3).

entries.name: 1. The Dining Room - Montarthas Manor
entries: The party enters the General's dining room via an open entrance from the manor's tea room. As they step into the area, the place comes alive. The empty room with an abandoned, rotting wooden table manifests a ghostly dinner party.
When the party enters, read or paraphrase the following:

As you step up into the dining room from the sunken tea room, the air grows warm. Suddenly, the room comes to life, as a half-dozen ghostly apparitions appear seated at the once empty table. It seems a large dinner party is being held, as a roasted hog materializes, along with plates of all varieties of food. Jugs of foaming ale are being shared between ghostly companions.

While the food on the plates looks spectral, and the mugs appear insubstantial, the hog looks solid, real, and delicious. A large spectral human man stands at the head of the table, saying nothing, a serious scowl and frown is cemented over his face as he overlooks his guests who seem to be enjoying themselves.
Carol Anne's voice whispers in your ear, "I am hungry."
The ghosts pay no heed to the heroes providing they do not interact with them.
If the heroes attempt to interact with any of the ghostly dinner party, read or paraphrase the following:

The room abruptly becomes quiet. All talking and laughter has ceased. Every ghost in the room is now facing you when the man at the head of the table rushes towards you, floating right through the hard wooden dining table and knocking the roasted hog on to the floor.
"You should not be here! LEAVE THIS PLACE!!!!"
Roll initiative!

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The inhabitants of the party, including the large man, are ghosts (MM p. 147). There are seven ghosts in total, and they fight until destroyed or the party leaves the area with or without the roast.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: The purpose of this quest is to get a piece of the roast for Carol Anne and leave the room with it.
Once a member of the party has a piece of the roast in hand and steps out of the dining room, they are teleported back to the Space Between, succeeding in their mission.

{@b Failure}. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest has been failed (keep a tally as the adventure progresses). If the adventurers leave the room without interacting with anything, the dinner party simply disappears as the party returns to the Space Between, also having failed.

entries.name: 2. The Guests Wash Room - Montarthas Manor
entries: This room has a large washing tub and a bench that stretches around the south-western corner of the room. An old bloodied towel hangs from a towel rack.
Read or paraphrase the following:

As you enter what looks to be an old washroom, you first notice the bloodied towel hanging from the towel rack. A wash tub sits along the northern wall of the room. A naked body lies within the otherwise empty tub, blood gushing from the woman's wrists. Carol Anne whispers, "I need a lock of mother's hair" as the body looks up at you, reaching out with elongating, gory arms.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The body is that of Carol Anne's mother, and it attempts to hug the party to death. She uses the statistics of the lonely (MToF pg. 232) and fights until destroyed.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: Once Carol Anne's mother is dead, the party can cut loose a lock of her hair, at which time, they return to the Space Between, victorious.
Failure. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without the hair, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: 3. The General's Waiting Room - Montarthas Manor
entries: A long bench stretches the northern wall of this extended waiting room. On the southern wall, two large oak doors stand closed. A tree is carved upon the door with leaves carved at the end of each branch, saying the names of each general that had served and lived within the manor, including their years of servitude. The Generals names appear from the earliest at the top to those later further down. The last name on the tree says "General Oscar Montarthas"; there are no more.
Read or paraphrase the following:

As you look around the room, it appears empty at first, but within the blink of an eye, a small pretty girl, no more than 5 or 6, is suddenly sitting on the long bench that stretches the northern wall. She seems to be waiting patiently. A dark and deadly looking woman appears in the room, smiles at the child, and offers her a children's doll. The girl smiles with joy as the woman evaporates. The child's smile turns to pain and anguish as blood soaked stab wounds begin to appear on her silky white dress. She falls limp and tumbles to the floor.
The doll is left lying on the bench, a knife in its hand. It turns to look at you with a grin on its face as Carol Anne whispers in your mind, "I need my faces. Both of them."
Roll initiative.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The Evil Doll attacks. She is at full legendary power here, and this time, she's not playing around. She fights to kill.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: In order to defeat this area, the party must retrieve the Evil Doll's face as well as Carol Anne's (though cutting their heads off works too).
Failure. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without both faces, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: 4. The Foyer - Montarthas Manor
entries: This room is trapped; the trap is triggered whenever a living soul passes beyond the line between the two statues (see The Foyer map).
Read or paraphrase the following when the heroes enter this room:

The entry foyer has a large open space with a floor of black marble. Two imposing looking demonic statues stand to either side of the foyer as if motionlessly keeping watch over the empty room. Carol Anne whispers in your ear "Wings to carry me to heaven."

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Parties who have played through The Haunt recognize a slight difference as these gargoyles are larger than they remember... and have four arms. These are giant four-armed gargoyles (ToA p. 221) and each of them animates as soon as the trap is triggered. They fight to the death.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: To succeed on this quest the party must retrieve a pair of wings from one of the gargoyles. Once the gargoyles are destroyed this is fairly easy to achieve.

Failure. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without two gargoyle wings, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: 5. The Library - Montarthas Manor
entries: As the party enters the library, read or paraphrase the following:
All four walls of this room are badly burnt.

There is ash and rubble littered across the floor, mixed in amongst the remains of old burnt books from ages past. Faintly, in amongst the remains, can be seen the slightly hidden piles of humanoid skeletons. The only thing that seems intact and whole in this room is a leather cloak draped over the half melted remains of a metal coat stand in the deepest corner of the room.
Beneath this coat stand is a children's book.
The slightly scorched cover reads "Blinsky's Blunders" in common. Carol Anne whispers in your ear, "Get me my bedtime stories."

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When a member of the party steps within 10 feet of the book, the two bookshelves along the east and west walls spring to life and attack, revealing themselves to be giant mimics (MotG p. 68). One attempts to block the exit, while the other attacks the party at its melee range. Interestingly, the cloak on the coat rack is just a normal cloak.

If the party attempt to gather the book via the likes of the mage hand cantrip or levitate spell or similar, the giant mimics reveal themselves and attempt to attack and swallow the book (AC 15) with their pseudopod, meaning the characters must kill the mimic to retrieve the book.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: The party must succeed in retrieving Blinsky's Blunders and moving out of the room.

Failure. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without Blinsky's Blunders, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: 6. Chapel - St. Greycastle's
entries: The doors leading into the chapel from the north are made of crumbling wood and hang askew on their hinges. A gap wide enough for a medium or smaller sized creature to squeeze through is formed as the doors lie, but a successful {@b {@dc 12} Strength (Athletics)} check pulls the rotten wood free from its hinges.
Once the characters can see inside the room, read or paraphrase the following:
Inside the room, it is immediately obvious this was once a beautiful chapel. Now, however, the room contains broken pews and shreds of rotten tapestries are scattered across the floor.

At the southern end of the old chapel sits a broken altar. Before the alter are shattered holy symbols and tools of divine ritual splayed out across the floor. Sitting in the center of the shattered altar is a badly beaten and bloodied winged creature. Around the creature's neck is an amulet bearing the holy symbol of Ilmater.
Carol Anne whispers in your ear, "I need Ilmater's Comfort."

At first glance, on a successful {@b {@dc 10} Intelligence (Religion)} check this appears to be a wounded deva, who pleads for any soul who happens upon it to lend aid. Those who approach the creature and have a passive Wisdom (Perception) score of 10 or above or who succeed a {@b {@dc 10} Wisdom (Perception)} check notice that it exudes a sulfurous odor. Characters who have survived this encounter in The Haunt 2 know this deva's true nature.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The wounded deva attempts to touch any creature who approaches within reach. Once it does, it makes a pseudopod attack initiating combat, revealing its true nature as an adult oblex (MToF p. 218). Any character with truesight can see the adult oblex in its true form.

There is also a netherchild (Appendix A) in the corner of the room, hidden in shadow. A successful {@b {@dc 20} Wisdom (Perception)} check notices the netherchild. Once initiative is rolled, the netherchild chuckles and casts a hallow spell, which drives out any celestials in the room and adds a silence effect throughout the chamber. The netherchild then flees the room.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: To succeed in this quest, the party must retrieve the amulet bearing the holy symbol of Ilmater from the adult oblex, and leave the area.

{@b Failure}. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without the amulet of Ilmater's holy symbol, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: 7. The Maternity Ward - St. Greycastle's
entries: This is a 20-foot by 40-foot chamber. Six adult beds with adjacent bassinets sit along the walls.
Three-bed sets sit against the east wall. All of the beds are filthy, covered in dust, dirt and old, dried blood.
Read or paraphrase the following:

The bed in the northwest corner is splattered with fresh, wet blood. The faint sound of a baby crying can be heard from the bloodied bassinet next to this bed, Carol Anne whispers in your ear, "I need you to bring me my brother's body."

Characters entering this area with a passive Wisdom (Perception) of 16 or above, who succeed on a {@b {@dc 16} Wisdom (Perception)} check, who spend one minute looking over the area succeeding on a {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} check, or those who survived The Haunt 2 notice an area in the center of the floor where the floorboards are unstable from being rotten through; failure results in those who try to cross the room crashing through the floorboards.

Those falling through the floorboards must succeed a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw to catch the side of the still intact stable floor; failure results in the PC falling through the floor and landing inside a giant gelatinous cube (MM p. 242) suffering an automatic failed save against the cube's Engulf feature.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The gelatinous cube fills the entire room beneath and any engulfed creature can try to escape on their turn by taking an action to make a {@dc 12} Strength check to swim up through the cube and back through the hole in the floor above.

Once a creature enters the space adjacent to the bloody basinet, a netherchild forsaken, Carol Anne's stillborn brother, leaps out of the bloody bassinet, attempting to grapple the nearest creature, initiating combat.
When combat begins, the remaining bassinets in the room begin bleeding. On the netherchild forsaken's next initiative, it uses its Wail attack.
If no character fell through the rotten floorboards, the netherchild forsaken's Wail breaks the rotten wood away, leaving a hole in the floor.

When the wail occurs, eight netherchildren rise up out of the forming blood pools, one in each bassinet. All creatures fight to the death while attempting to drag the heroes through the hole in the floor.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: Taking the netherchild forsaken's corpse from the room succeeds in this quest.

Failure. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without the netherchild forsaken's body, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: 8. Privy Chamber - St. Greycastle's
entries: This is the bathroom/privy area of the manor.
Read or paraphrase the following:

The walls and floor are splattered with a foul smelling ichor. The sound of an infant crying emanates from beneath an overturned chamber pot. Carol Anne whispers in your ear, "my heart weeps. I need it back."
If the chamber pot is moved or investigated, it reveals an unrecognizable chunk of bloody meat.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: As soon as the heroes investigate the chamber pot and see the chunk of bloody meat for the first time a specter (MM p. 279) bursts forth from it in a shower of gore, surprising the nearest character if they fail a {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom (Perception)} check.

The specter attacks the nearest character with mindshatter, then attempts to possess the target. Regardless of whether the possession is successful, the spectre fights until destroyed, doing everything it can to keep the lump of meat in the room.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: Succeeding in this quest means that all the heroes need to leave with the bloody chunk of meat.

Failure. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without the lump of bloody meat, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: 9. Nurses Quarters - St. Greycastle's
entries: Once the characters open the door to this room, read or paraphrase the following:

This room is filled with dry rotted wooden furniture, rusty medical equipment, and filthy, desecrated text. At the center of the room is a sketchbook filled with pastel drawings. In each corner of the room stands a faceless, twisted woman in a nurse's outfit. All four slowly turn in unison toward you as Carol Anne whispers in your ear, "I need my sketchbook...and I think they can smell you."
If inspected, the texts are procedures on the healing arts.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Standing in the room are four bleeder nurses, who attack anything that moves in the area. If the characters use the mage hand cantrip or similar to try and retrieve the sketchbook, the two closest bleeder nurses to the characters attack.

entries.name: Success or Failure
entries: To succeed at this quest, the heros need to obtain the sketchbook to return to Carol Anne.

Failure. If any member of the party is reduced to 0 hp, or if any member of the party abandons the room without the sketchbook, the entire party is returned to the Space Between and the quest is failed.

entries.name: Chapter 4: Endings
entries: The party's performance up to this point determines the ending they face.

entries.name: 4.1 The Good
entries: If the party succeeds on a total of six quests, they find themselves transported through time to the outskirts of the city. Standing at the edge of the road, they see a beautiful woman approaching the city. As she draws close, her disguise slips, revealing her to be the Night Hag (MM p. 178), Gertrude. This gives the party the opportunity to destroy Gertrude before she corrupts the Montarthas family.

entries.name: 4.2 The Bad
entries: If the party succeeds at only five quests, they are transported to the Sanitarium in St. Gertrude's.
Read or paraphrase the following:

Carol Anne is strapped to a bed. Her crystal blue eyes wide in pain. A bleeder nurse stands on either side of her, shoving various medical implements and arcane devices into her arms, legs, and chest. Gertrude steps up to the foot of the bed, carrying the lifeless and limp Evil Doll.
"Don't struggle, Carol Anne," Gertrude whispers.
"This is for the best. You like to play, yes? This will let us play together forever! Don't you want to play with us... forever?"
As she finishes the last sentence, Gertrude's attractive face melts away, revealing her true form, as that of a twisted hag.
This gives the party the chance to fight off Gertrude and save Carol Anne, though it is too late for General Montarthas and the rest of the family at this point.

entries.name: 4.3 The Ugly
entries: If the party fails a sixth quest, they return to the first challenge that they failed and come to the horrific realization that they are now trapped in an endless time loop in the Space Between. They have failed utterly. Carol Anne is damned, and now, so are they. This ends the adventure leaving the characters in eternal damnation.

entries.name: Denouement
entries: If Gertrude is defeated in either scenario, the party returns to the present, on the grounds of St. Greycastle's.

If the good ending was achieved, the hospital still stands. The city around it bustles with activity. A beautiful, elderly woman dressed in healer's garb steps out of the door and approaches the group.
"Thank you," she says with a smirk. "It worked."
This is Carol Anne, an adult who now leads the healers at St. Greycastle's.
If asked, Carol Anne explains that her longevity in life is a strange side effect from the supernatural ordeals her soul faced during the events of The Haunt series.

If the bad ending was achieved, the party arrives at the ruins of St. Greycastle's, much in the state they are found in at the beginning of The Haunt 2. An elderly woman, dressed in wizard's robes approaches the group. Removing her hood, she introduces herself as Carol Anne and invites the group to her Manor, where she feeds them and explains that she has studied magic her whole life to keep the area safe from orcs and hags. She thanks the group and offers them one rare magic item of their choice in exchange for their service (DM's discretion).
If asked, Carol Anne explains that her longevity in life is a strange side effect from the supernatural ordeals her soul faced during the events of The Haunt series.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the evil doll remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary, inanimate children's doll.

trait.name: Frightening Lullaby
entries: Once per day, the evil doll can use a bonus action to sing a creepy children's lullaby. All creatures within a 30 ft. radius, that can hear it, must succeed a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw.  On a failed saving throw the creature becomes {@condition frightened} and must succeed on another {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw to break the enchantment at the end of their next turn. On a second failed save, the creature then becomes {@condition paralyzed}, and can attempt a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw on each turn.  Once it has succeeded a saving throw, the creature is no longer {@condition paralyzed}

trait.name: Shadow Blend {@recharge 5}
entries: As a bonus action, the evil doll can disappear to the evil places that lurk in the shadows. Use this feature as an escape mechanism.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The evil doll makes two attacks: one with its knife and one with its claw.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. Hit 7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Knife
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. Hit 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The oblex's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The oblex can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Aversion to Fire
entries: If the oblex takes fire damage, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Sulfurous Impersonation
entries: As a bonus action, the oblex can extrude a piece of itself that assumes the appearance of one Medium or smaller creature whose memories it has stolen.
This simulacrum appears, feels, and sounds exactly like the creature it impersonates, though it smells faintly of sulfur.

The oblex can impersonate {@dice 1d4 + 1} different creatures, each one tethered to its body by a strand of slime that can extend up to 120 feet away. For all practical purposes, the simulacrum is the oblex, meaning that the oblex occupies its space and the simulacrum's space simultaneously. The slimy tether is immune to damage, but it is severed if there is no opening at least 1 inch wide between the oblex's main body and the simulacrum. The simulacrum disappears if the tether is severed.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The oblex makes one pseudopod attack and uses Eat Memories.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage.

action.name: Eat Memories
entries: The oblex targets one creature it can see within 5 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) psychic damage and become memory drained until it finishes a short or long rest or until it benefits from the greater restoration or {@spell heal} spell.
Constructs, oozes, plants, and undead succeed on the save automatically.

While memory drained, the target must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from any ability check or attack roll it makes. Each time the target is memory drained beyond the first, the die size increases by one: the {@dice d4} becomes a {@dice d6}, the {@dice d6} becomes a {@dice d8}, and so on until the die becomes a {@dice d20}, at which point the target becomes {@condition unconscious} for 1 hour. The effect then ends.
When an oblex causes a target to become memory drained, the oblex learns all the languages the target knows and gains all its proficiencies, except for any saving throw proficiencies.

trait.name: Blinded
entries: The bleeder nurse cannot see. It relies on its Sense

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The bleeder nurse's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Reactive
entries: The bleeder nurse can take one reaction on every turn in a combat.

trait.name: Sense Movement
entries: The Bleeder nurse knows the exact location of any other creature who uses 15 feet or more of movement while within 30 feet of the bleeder nurse. The bleeder nurse suffers no penalty for being {@condition blinded} when attacking a creature detected via sense movement until the end of the bleeder nurse's next turn.

trait.name: Sentinel
entries: The bleeder nurse has all the benefits of the sentinel feat

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bleeder nurse makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage. On a hit, the target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw suffering an additional 21 ({@dice 6d6}) hit points due to blood loss on a failed save, and half as much on a success. If the target fails its Constitution save, it takes an additional 21 ({@dice 6d6}) hit points due to blood loss on the end of each of the bleeder nurse's turns. A successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or receiving magical healing will end this effect. If the target or an ally uses one action and expends one use of a healer's kit, succeeding on a {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom (Medicine)} check will stop the bleeding.

reaction.name: Parry

entries: This green emerald is an ancient relic imbued with necrotic energies by an evil necromancer long ago.

As a bonus action the emerald's master can use it to transfer {@dice 3d6} Hit Points from the victim to them-self if it is within 60 ft. The emerald has two charges per day and regains all of its charges at dawn.

The gem exerts no control over the victim otherwise, but the master of the emerald knows it's direction and distance at all times. If the emerald crosses into another plane, the owner knows which one.

entries.name: Extraction
entries: A skilled physician can remove the gem on a successful {@dc 17} Intelligence ({@skill Medicine}) check, but the patient suffers {@damage 4d10} piercing damage on every attempt. A greater restoration spell can be used to eject the gem.
